CatDescriptText: Mr. Robert Minter, postal clerk, 12th Ward and Mr. John Kelly, steelworker, Fifth Avenue, were part of the Pittsburghers Speak Up column published in Pittsburgh Courier newspaper, October 14, 1961, pg. 7 with question: "Do you think political leaders, who have been granted the power of seeking or dispensing patronage should "take care" of their immediate family and relatives before they do such supporters like committee men and committee women and financial contributors?"  Mr. Minter's answer reads: "Supporters should be first...However, most of the time leaders choose first the members of their immediate families who are not qualified."  Mr. Kelly's answer reads: "They should take care of the majority of people before members of their immediate families because those former people put them into office.  However, always they first fry to place their immediate families."
TitMainTitle: Two frames: Portrait of Robert Minter wearing light colored pinstriped suit jacket, standing in front of woman, storefront, and buildings; Portrait of John Kelly wearing striped necktie and hat, standing in front of row of store fronts, back facing man, and buildings
